narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was a virtual seminar and weekly recorded lecture.
Recorded lecture
Recorded lectures from the DS H&P Faculty along with synchronous virtual discussion sections.
The class also included a weekly virtual lecture, which was asynchronous.
Recorded Lecture
Recorded lectures
Pre-recorded online lecture

* virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Knowledge: early methodology of history, early political theory
Skills: how to read carefully and closely, how to evaluate and compare different thinkers, writing

I learned the most about writing in H&P, thanks to Professor Semmel's detailed feedback on both what I was saying and how I could get it across in the best possible way.

I learned so much in this course.  I was worried that the course content wouldn't feel relevant, but I was completely wrong.  I found the histories that we read to be particularly engaging.
Ancient history, as well as analysis to historical texts.

I learned how to examine historical and political texts more critically and from an analytical point of view. This class also really helped me hone my writing skills. The class was also really interesting in its subject material.

I learned to read efficiently. I learned to write quickly and systematically. The course focused on ancient historiography and political theory, and much of our time in seminar was spent engaging in ancient debates on the nature of history and political community.
My essay writing skill improved and I learned to draw connections between the ideas of several authors.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Semmel is incredible, and he made the course as amazing as it was.  I think another strength is that we cover a lot of material.  This does mean that the class goes quickly, though.

Weaknesses: Sometimes, we spent a lot more time on one text (eg, the Republic) than another, which felt uneven.  I also think that the reading could be reduced even more, particularly this year given the challenging circumstances, and made more inclusive and diverse.

I really loved the format of the class and supplementing our readings with lectures and synchronous discussions. The texts were carefully chosen and interacted with each other very well in H&P and across the different DS sections.

This course was strong on breadth and weak on depth. Unlike other DS courses, we rarely read works from cover to cover. Almost everything we read was excerpted. I would have liked to read one or two more full works, even at the expense of some other selections. Besides the reading, this course included a substantial writing component which prioritized the presence of good ideas over any polish in their presentation. This was a useful priority in the first year.

The seminars went very well. Sometimes the lectures were uploaded later than I would've liked since I had class Monday and would not have time to watch it before seminar, so releasing the lectures earlier would help.
There was a lot of reading that was sometimes difficult to manage so early in the week.

The course readings were more varied than I expected (I really liked what the inclusion of Al Farabi and Maimonides added to it). However, sometimes it felt to me like we were reading a bunch of texts without a clear direction of learning. The course could be improved by more discussion of the ultimate takeaways

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Professor Semmel used breakout rooms really well, which I appreciated because it allowed me to think out loud in class and engage more with other students.  

I think the course could be improved by having more informal Zoom office hours for the whole class.
I felt the course was adapted very well in regard to COVID-19. The virtual discussion sections greatly facilitated learning, and I always felt super engaged.
Virtual seminars ran well. Breakout rooms, when used, facilitated an even more organic discussion. They could be used more frequently.
Virtual seminars worked well, I can't think of anything that would improve it given the circumstances.

It was hard to keep up on watching the lectures before classes because I had trouble finishing the readings with any time to spare. I did not get nearly as much out of the lectures as I would have liked because I didn't end up watching most of them. They were recorded to be watched on our own time, the flexibility of which was both a blessing and a curse. I realize that if they were in person then the only difference would have been that they were at a fixed time and so I would have had to watch them then whether I had finished the reading or not--thus one could say that I should have just imposed a time when I had to watch the lecture whether I was done or not. That does not feel very satisfying either, though, so I'm not sure what my takeaway thought is.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially with Professor Semmel!  I was on the fence about DS, but I'm so glad I decided to do it.  The things I heard about DS are pretty accurate--you do have to be prepared for a lot of reading and (especially fall semester) a focus on ancient, Eurocentric texts--but if you're okay with that, it's an amazing program.
YESS!!!!
Yes! Especially if you are interested in the DS subject material. You will have a great time in H&P!! The discussions were always super interesting.
DS can be unpleasant, and it's not for everyone. DS seminars are worth it.
Yes, this was a fun class to be in and I really enjoyed discussing the readings with the class.
